header.title: Imperial Arts Volume One
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Grimoire Tradition, Demonology

central_thesis: The author aims to demonstrate the practical efficacy and proper form of ancient Solomonic magical traditions, specifically Goetia, for conjuring spirits to obtain demonstrable services and knowledge. The work emphasizes a rigorous, traditional approach, documenting personal experiments to validate magical claims and distinguish them from impostures, while providing insights into the spirits' natures and powers.

structure_content.summary: The author recounts his childhood fascination with the supernatural and subsequent dissatisfaction with conventional explanations for miracles. He describes his journey into demonology, seeking reliable first-hand accounts of demonic powers in action, and his eventual decision to personally experiment with grimoires due to the lack of credible practitioners and scientific investigations into magic.

This chapter establishes the primary objective of the work: the conjuration of demons for specific services and disclosure of unknown facts. The author identifies his source as Sloane Ms. 2731, known as Lemegeton or the Lesser Key of Solomon. He provides historical context for Solomon's reputed power over spirits and details the Goetia's account of 72 demons, their binding, release, and continued subjugation through divine names. The core ceremonial objective is outlined: compelling spirits to appear in a triangle and answer requests.

The author outlines his streamlined, personal approach to Goetic ceremonies, emphasizing strict adherence to traditional procedures. He details the 'P.R.A.C.T.I.C.E. of Evocation': Purgation (cleaning), Retreat (mental preparation), Ablution (physical cleansing with Psalm 51), Commitment (setting up ritual space and tools), Timing (Moon phase, day of spirit's office), Incantations (prayers from Artem Novem), Conjurations (Call, Invocation, Constraint), and Exorcism (curses, burning of the spirit's seal if disobedient). He also describes the specific ritual tools and their preparation.

This extensive section details the author's conjuration experiences with various Goetic spirits. Each entry provides the spirit's name, Hebrew etymology (where applicable), rank, number of legions, appearance, and the interactions, questions, and commands exchanged. Key experiences include Agares causing an earthquake, Bime's refusal to grant riches directly, Naphula teaching craftsmanship, Oriax's insights into astrology and human transformation, Eligor foretelling wars and securing influence, Purson discussing metaphysics and revealing hidden treasures, Haagenti offering counsel on alchemy, Amduscias's wisdom on nature and tree bending, Gaap's role in influencing people and fostering knowledge, Gusion bestowing honor, Amon's assessment of the magician's character, Beleth's obstinate nature and demand for reciprocal love, Dantalion's ability to alter thoughts and create visionary artifacts, Haures's discourse on divinity and destructive power, Cairn's predictions on climate change, Shax's power to manipulate perception, Bathin's ability to compel relocation, and Gomory's influence over affection and revealing hidden treasures. The author records both successes and challenges in controlling and understanding the spirits.

This chapter revisits the earlier evocations to tabulate and evaluate their outcomes. The author reports on the fulfillment of demands, unexpected consequences (e.g., his mother's death after Bime's conjuration, personal afflictions from spirits), and the observable effects on his life and the world. He reflects on his successes in gem craftsmanship (Naphula), acquiring property (Shax), influencing people (Dantalion), and the unexpected White House invitation (Berith). He maintains a skeptical yet open-minded stance, noting where predictions were accurate, where his understanding was refined, and where results remain pending or ambiguous. He also uses this section to further critique common occult practices and reinforce his adherence to traditional methods.

The author discusses the lack of a coherent body of 'Medieval Magic' and critiques various New Age interpretations, particularly Crowley's 'Initiated Interpretation' of Goetia, for misrepresenting the true nature and practices of grimoire traditions. He asserts that true magic involves distinct spirits, specific rituals, and the magician acting as an agent of God, bound by covenants. He proposes a 'Brotherhood of the Lion of God' to explore, educate, and exploit magical powers, outlining its goals, restrictions (e.g., no women or homosexuals, no paid work), obligations, and sequential levels of advancement, emphasizing a rigorous, materials-based approach to practice.
The author thanks readers, collaborators (J. Jones, Nick K., W. Long, Vaso G.), and his wife Sarah for their support, contributions, and editorial assistance in the creation of the book.

key_concepts.term: Goetia / Lemegeton / Lesser Key of Solomon
key_concepts.definition: The primary grimoire tradition and source text for the author's practical ceremonial magic, describing the conjuration of 72 bound spirits for various purposes. It emphasizes specific rituals, tools, and divine names to compel obedience from these spirits, who were originally sealed by King Solomon.

The necessary tools and conditions for performing Goetic ceremonies. These include specific vestments (robe, hat, lion's skin belt, ring, medallion), ritual implements (sword, brazier, chain, ebony box with sulphur/asafoetida, wooden tablet), and consecrated spaces (Circle of Solomon, red calf-skin Hexagram, triangle of manifestation).

The ritualistic process of communicating with and commanding spiritual entities to appear and perform specific tasks. It involves distinct phases: Purgation, Retreat, Ablution, Commitment, Timing, Incantations (prayers like Artem Novem), and specific Conjurations (Call, Invocation, Constraint).

Engraved symbols of individual spirits, made of specific metals (e.g., gold for Kings, silver/copper for Earls, mercury for Presidents), which are crucial for binding and commanding the spirits. The author describes making his own seals using lost-wax castings or sheet metal.

The protective ritual space (a white 10'x10' rug with a detailed circular design) within which the magician stands, and the separate triangular space (2 feet off the circle, 3 feet in diameter) outside the circle where the spirit is compelled to manifest and answer commands.

A spirit, obtainable from Purson (#20), that acts as an audible guide to the magician, assisting with practical tasks (e.g., navigating terrain, revealing information). It is given freely as a gift and invoked by speaking its name while holding its seal.

A title for the magician (derived from Greek 'O Kti Nomos'), signifying 'one who makes the law.' It denotes the magician's authority over the spirits, who are bound to obey his dictates according to the terms of the ceremony.

A theoretical vessel into which spirits can be conjured and sealed, making them readily available for later use. The Pentacle alone is sufficient for commanding spirits thus sealed, simplifying subsequent interactions.

key_concepts.term: Brotherhood of the Lion of God
key_concepts.definition: The author's envisioned organization for practitioners of traditional magic. It proposes a structured system of voluntary advancement through nine levels, with specific restrictions, obligations (e.g., contributions of metals), and the provision of authentic ritual materials and facilities for members.

practical_system.description: The author's practical system is a literal and stringent application of Goetic conjuration derived from Sloane Ms. 2731. It emphasizes meticulous preparation, precise execution of rituals, and direct command of spirits rather than alliances or worship. The system is designed to compel the 72 spirits of Solomon to appear, communicate, and perform requested tasks, leveraging divine names and established covenants. A core principle is maintaining authority over the spirits, distinguishing this approach from many modern interpretations.
tools: Lion's skin belt (3 inches wide with 45 Hebrew names in India ink)
Medallion (bearing the spirit's seal in its proper metal with the pentacle of Solomon on the reverse side)
Wooden tablet with several sheets of paper and a pencil (for notes and bindings)
Red calf-skin (bearing the Hexagram of Solomon, covered in a white linen cloth)
White 10'x10' rug with the Circle of Solomon (red central square, four blue hexagrams, two concentric gold circles with 'The Names' in black between them)
Four candle stands with white candles
Hyssop oil (for anointing temples and brows)
rituals: Purgation: Thorough cleaning of the ritual space and self-preparation without arranging items.
Retreat: A period of spiritual and mental isolation, focusing on scripture, divination, contemplation, fasting (water only), and avoiding business or leisure.
Ablution: Bathe and wash hands/face one hour before the ceremony, reciting a portion of Psalm 51.
Commitment (Exterior): Rolling out the consecrated rug (Circle of Solomon), placing four candle stands with white candles, and marking out the Triangle of Manifestation.
Commitment (Interior): Placing the brazier, a small table, and paper for notes within the magician's circle.

Timing: Performing the ceremony at the beginning of the spirit's 'office hours', determined by Moon phase (waxing, even-numbered day from first visible appearance) and Jewish calendar, with spirit rank determining time of day.

Vesting: Donning the white linen robe, lion's skin belt (with 45 Hebrew names), gold ring (with 3 names), medallion (spirit's seal with Pentacle of Solomon reverse), and pointed white canvas hat. Anointing temples and brows with Hyssop oil. Saying vesting prayers, likely composed of Hebrew words (Ancor, Amacor, Amides, Theodonias, Anitor) as incantations from Artem Novem.
Incantations: Reciting prayers from Artem Novem at the center of the circle, with the sword laid over blank pages.
Conjurations: Speaking aloud the 'Call', 'Invocation', and 'Constraint' while facing the triangle, clearly and directly. Errors require restarting the specific conjuration.
Address to the Spirit: Displaying the Seal of Solomon (a Hexagram bearing conjuration terms) and commanding the spirit's obedience, proclaiming the magician's authority as 'Octinomos'.
Welcome Speech & Incense: After the spirit assumes its humbled form, delivering a welcome speech and burning Benzoin and Myrrh incense.
Giving Charges: Communicating specific questions and commands (tasks) to the spirit, often referring to a written list. The spirit must consent to these charges.

Exorcism/Condemnations (if disobedient): First, calling the Cardinal Kings in their quarters. If insufficient, folding the spirit's seal, placing it in a chained box with sulphur and asafoetida, making fire in the brazier, reciting the Chain Curse, and finally burning the box (and seal) in the fire, followed by the Curse of Darkness. This compels manifestation by depriving the spirit of its office and place.
License to Depart: Granting the spirit permission to leave after commands are accepted or performed.

relevant_quotes.text: The only way to gain a worthwhile opinion on the subject, for my own satisfaction, was to make the experiments myself.

I believe the Goetia and all true magical arts ought to be regarded with extreme caution. It is often not so terrible to be stuck without the right tools, or to speak a word incorrectly, or to perform the ceremony badly; but to make unwise wishes can lead quickly to difficulty or disaster when they are guaranteed fulfillment. Getting what you want while wanting something stupid is the greatest danger in any magical art.
The spirit appeared as a tall man wearing a bulky robe of a color and texture similar to his seal in fixed mercury and inlay of tin.
This is a spirit that knows what lies buried deep within the hearts of people, and he is able to stir those faults at will.

The spirits are bound to peculiar terms over which the magician has little control, and to establish one's own terms to the same effect requires a sort of leverage or merit seldom found among men of any age.
S - "I will always be your Best Friend. I will do what you have demanded."

critical_analysis.relevance: This book offers a rare first-hand account of the practical application of the Goetia in a modern context, rigorously adhering to historical grimoire instructions. It is highly relevant for demonstrating how such complex systems are intended to be operative, contrasting sharply with purely theoretical or psychological interpretations common in contemporary occultism. The author's commitment to documenting both successes and failures, alongside his detailed explanations of ritual mechanics and spirit interactions, provides invaluable data for practitioners and scholars of esotericism.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience includes advanced practitioners and serious academic researchers in Western Esotericism and Occultism, particularly those interested in grimoire traditions, Solomonic magic, and demonology. It is also suitable for individuals seeking a detailed, pragmatic, and non-speculative account of ceremonial magic. Due to the inherent complexities and potential dangers discussed, it is not recommended for novice practitioners or those seeking a casual introduction to magic.
